{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3582767,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-07T18:09:00.717Z","cooked":"

This is our second year in Python and first with Magicbot. We’re seeing loop overruns in teleop pretty consistently, like they just scroll right on by in the console log, and disabledPeriodic does the same for much the same reasons.

(Code is all here: GitHub - TheTriSonics/Reefscape2025: Robot code for Reefscape)

The offenders seem to be the drivetrain.py’s execute() and vision.py’s execute() and for the life of me I cannot think of a way to make them do less or go faster at this point. In the case of drivetrain it spends almost all the time in update_odometry() which is just a call to wpilib, and vision’s system is much the same, where we’re either getting NT data from PhotonVision or in wpilib code to add a vision measurement.

For the life of me I can’t see how a different framework or language would fare any better at execution speed with what we’re doing, but others on the team seem to think reverting to Java to command based might help. Personally, I’m not seeing how they would help. We’re just doing a lot each cycle with trying to pull in 4 vision poses and integrate that into odometry. I don’t think the RIO2 can keep up but then again I might be calling wpilib in a manner that’s not proper and I just can’t see it.

Dumping vision and odometry updates into an executor outside the main robot code might help in this instance. I would like to take a stab at that now that our season is done.

Are the loop overruns causing any issues for you guys? We get them a bunch too but we just ignore them. I remember there was another post about how to get rid of the logs, but I can’t find where it was.

Justin_Buist:

It’s not causing any performance issue that I can tell. It just has people saying Python is slow.

Python is much slower than Java, but most of the time it doesn’t matter – and in your case here, if everything is working then how much does it actually matter?

With that said, for some teams that have a lot of stuff that they’re trying to get their robot to do, it has been a problem, and some teams have switched away from Python because of that. Unfortunately nobody has really done any work that I’m aware of to characterize performance in RobotPy, and I’m not really in a position to do so.

It is expected that with the improved 2027 controller the performance issues with Python will no longer be relevant for 99.99% of teams.

I know this really isn’t an apples to apples comparison, but 4611 noticed little to no change in loop times after switching from Java to Python this year while doing very similar levels of onboard processing (and trust me we’re willing to run our Rio pretty hard). The only major difference in performance we had came as a result of the fact that we couldn’t multithread because of the lack of an addPeriodic method in MagicBot.

This is definitely a hack, but if you have timeouts happening not because of your code itself, you can have the timeouts be taken care of in a different context than the standard processing.

My team once ran a season doing all the talking to the radio in interrupt context because we couldn’t figure out what in our code was making us hit watchdogs. It turned out there was a physical flaw in the robot controller, which is why we couldn’t find a problem in the code.

I’m not saying that it’s a great idea to do this, but you could have something taking care of the timer in one thread (or process) and the actual number crunching happen elsewhere. If you decide to do this still in Python, you may need to explore how your Python implementation deals with locking.
